assignments.description: Overall course participation grade (see syllabus for further detail).
assignments.name: Overall Course Participation

assignments.description:
Upload a brief (one paragraph, 3-4 sentences, max) Individual Bio that describes your background and interests relevant to an industry-sponsored capstone project. This is your first opportunity to give a positive first impression to your potential teammates and to your course instructor.

After reading your bio, the reader should understand:

  • Your technical strengths
  • Your non-technical attributes/abilities
  • Your personality/individual brand

Your individual bio should include:

  • Headshot: this does not need to be a formal photo, but should be appropriate for delivery to an industry partner.
  • Bio: keep this as concise as possible, with a focus on specific languages, technologies, or projects you have worked on that are directly relevant to an industry-sponsored capstone project.
assignments.name: Individual Bio
assignments.lock_explanation: This assignment was locked Jan 10 at 1:30pm.

assignments.description:
Record and upload a 2-minute (max) video highlighting your past experiences, technical skills, and any projects or accomplishments that demonstrate your strengths in computer science. Focus on what sets you apart as a potential teammate or collaborator, and how your skills could be valuable to industry partners. Be clear, concise, and engaging, aiming to communicate your unique strengths to both your classmates and professionals in the field.

  • The video should feel intentional - use your individual bio as a jumping off point and refine/edit for verbal (rather than written) delivery. 
  • Appropriate attire and video background are expected.
  • Video due by end of regular lab time on Friday (3:15pm 1/10) - assignment moved online for weather related university shut-down.

View and take notes on 3 other recordings over the weekend. Please do not write your comments in Canvas, we will discuss in class.

  • What do you know about this person?
  • Why might they make a great teammate?
  • What skills do they have that would be an asset to an industry partner?
assignments.name: 2-min Elevator Pitch
assignments.lock_explanation: This assignment was locked Jan 10 at 3:15pm.

assignments.description:
Based on feedback from your classmates and the course instructor, transform your individual bio into a product appropriate for a corporate/industry partner. 

These bios will be combined into a team bio page and delivered to your partner when we form teams next week. The team bio page is intended to inspire confidence in your team and your ability to work on an industry-sponsored project. All photos and bios should be effortful, intentional, and professional.

Your updated bio should include:

  • Headshot: use examples and suggestions from the class discussion to update your headshot if needed.
  • Bio: use feedback from your classmates and instructor, update your bio as needed. Focus on specific languages, technologies, or projects you have worked on that are directly relevant to an industry-sponsored capstone project - be concise, consistent, specific.
assignments.name: Updated Individual Bio
assignments.lock_explanation: This assignment was locked Jan 14 at 10am.

assignments.description:
This survey is intended to gauge your interest in specific industry projects this semester. 

Please provide your TOP THREE project choices, including a brief summary about why you chose those projects. Be specific.

Your interest statement might include details on why you chose a particular partner or why you chose a particular project topic.
assignments.name: Project Interest

assignments.description:
Be sure to thoroughly read the attached Student Participation Agreement. This participation agreement assigns intellectual property rights to Clemson University for the work you perform on your industry sponsored project this semester.

We will discuss in more detail in lab on Fri.

You will need to download, read, complete, and sign the Student Participation Agreement before you can begin technical work on the sponsored project.

If you do not agree to the terms included in the agreement, please do not sign. You will not be allowed to work on a sponsored project this semester, and will instead work on an alternate, non-sponsored project.

Upload your completed, signed agreement as a .pdf document.
assignments.name: Student Participation Agreement

assignments.description: Please attach a version of your resume in its current state.

assignments.description: Use the lessons from the class and examples to improve your resume.  Be sure to incorporate any feedback given from your instructor and/or your classmates regarding your first draft.

assignments.name: Midterm performance evaluations - sign up sheet

assignments.description: This survey is your opportunity to provide honest feedback on the performance of your team overall, your individual performance within the team, and the performance of each of your team members. For open ended questions, please limit your responses to one clear, concise paragraph. Your responses should include specific examples of the behavior or actions you are describing.
assignments.name: Midterm Project Contributions and Peer Evaluations_1

assignments.description:
Throughout the semester, we will be working on creating a professional Project Report that details both the technical (code and implementation) and non-technical (design process and project management) aspects of your project.

Your writing will be iterative in nature, meaning that we will write, edit, and add portions of the final report as we go. This report will be delivered to your industry partner at the end of the semester, and will be included in your overall project grade.

The first step of this process is to gain a deeper understanding of your industry partner by researching and writing a short (one page) report about your partner company.

After reading your report, the reader should clearly understand: 

    • Who the partner company is: their industry, market, vision/goals, etc.
    • Who the major identified stakeholders are: backgrounds and titles, roles, etc.

We will look for and choose an appropriate format for each of your final project reports later on in the semester. For now, your Partner Company Research Report should follow the formatting guidelines below:

  • 10 pt. font
  • Single spaced, 1" margins
  • Please use headers and sub-headers as appropriate
  • All submissions in .pdf format
  • Only the team leader will submit for the entire team
assignments.name: Partner Company Research Report

assignments.description:
You will work as a team to create your first Introductory Email with a Team Bio page for your industry partner.

The purpose of this email is to introduce your team and start a conversation to set a first meeting date/time. This email does not need to be overly complicated, but should be professional and include a one page attachment (in .pdf format) of your team bios. 

  • You must submit both your draft email text and your one page attachment for review in Canvas prior to sending to your project sponsor. Please do not email your partner until after I have approved your bio and email. When I have approved your bio and email, be sure to include me in cc. 
  • Your team bio page should be consistent across team members (first or third person, approx length, photo size/style). 
    • One page only
    • The final page should feel intentional, professional, and complete - formatting and visual design matter!
  • Please save project questions for a follow up email with your sponsor.
  • Only the team leader (or interim) will submit for the entire team.
assignments.name: Draft Email to Industry Partner + Team Bio Page

assignments.description:
Please submit GitHub user names for all team members. 

I will create a private repo for each team under our Capstone GitHub organization account.

  • Once the repos have been created, GitHub will send an individual email invitation to the email account that is associated with your user name. 
  • Be sure to check that email, if you did not use your clemson.edu account.

Only one submission per team.
assignments.name: GitHub User Names

assignments.description:
For this assignment, you will construct a Team Contract. This is your opportunity to work as a team to establish a shared understanding of the team project, team member roles within the project, and team expectations for quality and timeliness of individual and group work. This contract is an agreement between you and your teammates about how your team will operate, and a set of rules and expectations that you agree to abide by.

The assignment is most effective when all members of the team participate and share their ideas and expectations. Keep in mind that development projects are iterative in nature, and you more than likely will need to adjust some aspects of your team contract as the semester progresses. The team contract is a document that can and should be revised as your understanding of the project matures, you gain better insights into the needs and personal preferences of your team members, and as the work toward project completion takes form.

Please complete the assignment in a neat, professional manner using the attached template. 

  • Only one submission per team
  • Upload in .pdf format
assignments.name: Team Contract

assignments.description:
Step 1 Partner Company Research Report (completed)

Step 2 - create a Product Roadmap based on the information you have gathered about your project so far. 

A roadmap in agile development provides important context that empowers teams to reach both incremental and project-wide goals. Your roadmap should provide a high-level summary of the strategic goals of the project. The roadmap will serve as a jumping off point for creating your backlogs this week, and future sprint planning. You should work in collaboration with your industry partner to develop and refine the roadmap.

    • Major Milestones: each project will have its own unique initiatives and major milestones, depending on the type of project and desired client outcomes. Some examples include front and back end feature development activities, testing, project artifacts (report or technical documentation drafts and final versions), etc. 
    • Start date
    • End date
    • Duration

We will look for and choose an appropriate format for each of your final project reports later on in the semester. Your Product Roadmap is one section of that final report, and should follow the formatting guidelines below:

  • The product roadmap is a visual tool (graphic)
  • Must fit on a standard report page width, nicely formatted
    • Look for examples online
  • All submissions in .pdf format
  • Only the team leader will submit for the entire team
assignments.name: Sprint 0 Artifact 1 - Product Roadmap

assignments.description:
Step 1 Partner Company Research Report (completed)

Step 2 Product Roadmap (completed)

Step 3 User Personas (to be completed - only if applicable)

Step 4 of this process is to find or create a template for your Final Report, and create a topical outline of the sections that will be included. Your template should be developed in a way that it can be easily adapted as we add and refine sections over the next few weeks.

Your template should include the following elements and considerations:

  • Design
    • The look and feel of your template should be consistent with both your team's brand and the Clemson brand.
    • What first impression do you want to give the reader about your team and/or your project?
  • Formatting
    • Your template should use consistent formatting throughout, with appropriate use of headers and sub-headers, whitespace, and color.
    • Visually, how easy/difficult is your report to follow?

Your outline should include the following elements and considerations:

  • Major section headers: the major elements of your project, from inception to completion.
    • What is the story you are trying to tell?
    • Topically, how easy/difficult is your report to follow?
    • Is there a logical flow?
  • Section sub-headers: the minor supporting elements of each major section
    • Do your sub-sections support or further enhance the story?
    • Do they confuse the reader?
    • Is there a logical flow?

NOTE: the more time you spend thinking about and refining your outline, the easier it will be to assign sections and work to complete your final report.

  • All submissions in .pdf format
  • Only the team leader will submit for the entire team
assignments.name: Final Report Draft - Template + Outline

assignments.description:
Step 1 Partner Company Research Report (completed)

Step 2 Product Roadmap (completed)

Step 3 User Personas (completed - if applicable)

Step 4 Template + Outline (completed)

Step 5 of this process is to write the Introduction/Background, Project Scope, and Schedule sections of your Final Report.

Keep in mind that each industry project is unique, and your section needs may differ slightly from the heading titles above. These headings are flexible, and should remain consistent with your chosen format and outline developed in Step 4.

In general, these sections should cover the following information/topics:

Introduction/Background

  • Who the client is: their industry, market, vision/goals, etc.
  • Why the project came to be: high level description of when and how the client recognized a computer science related problem. 
  • What outcome will be achieved: high level description of the end state, from the client's perspective. Keep in mind this is not a technical description, this is a business goal-oriented description of the end state of the project. What will the business be able to do at the end of the project that they cannot do now?

Project Scope and Schedule

  • The scope of your project: a well-written statement that clearly defines the boundaries of the problem you addressed this semester. Your client may have expressed many needs and project ideas in early meetings, but you helped your client prioritize, choose, and refine the exact scope of your project. This paragraph (or two) helps to set the stage for the remainder of your project report.
  • High level project schedule (product roadmap): a graphic presentation of your project timeline, with major development milestones and timelines. 
  • All submissions in .pdf format
  • Only the team leader will submit for the entire team
assignments.name: Final Report Draft - Introduction/Background, Scope and Schedule

assignments.description:
Step 1 Partner Company Research Report (completed)

Step 2 Product Roadmap (completed)

Step 3 User Personas (completed - if needed)

Step 4 Template + Outline (completed)

Step 5 Introduction/Background, Scope, Schedule (completed)

Step 6 of this process is to begin formal documentation for the technical portions of your project, the Developer Guide and User Guide addendums to your Final Report.

Keep in mind that each industry project is unique, and your guides will be specifically tailored to your project needs. This documentation should remain consistent with your chosen format and outline developed in Step 4.

In general, these technical documents should cover the following information/topics:

Developer Guide

The goal of the developer guide is to help your client and/or a future capstone team to replicate and continue your work. It should include technical details on what you did and any information a developer would need to recreate your project.

  • Use graphics where appropriate to complement or enhance your written text. These may include tables, graphs, diagrams, or pictures that provide a high level view of a particular process flow, database design, integration, platform, user interface design, website design, etc. 
  • Keep your writing clear, concise, and organized. A client or future capstone team should be able to follow your developer guide step-by-step to recreate your project.

User Guide

The user guide should include necessary information for how to use and interact with your system. Keep this guide as simple as possible. The target audience are typical users, which in most cases may not have a technical background.

  • Visual cues are especially helpful for a user that is interacting with your system for the first time. These may include screenshots, pictures, and graphs that guide a user through a series of steps for creating an account, logging in, navigating a website, performing a task, using a dashboard, etc.
  • Keep your writing clear, concise, and organized. A client or future capstone team should be able to follow your user guide step-by-step to interact with your system.
  • All submissions in .pdf format
  • Only the team leader will submit for the entire team
assignments.name: Final Report Draft - Technical Documentation

assignments.description:
You will work as a team to create your first Show and Tell for your project and deliver a presentation to the instructor, your classmates, and both technical and non-technical visitors (if applicable). 

The purpose of the presentation is two-fold:

  1. Introduce your project to the audience and provide a midterm status update.
  2. Presentation practice: your first show and tell is an opportunity to practice presenting technical information and project status as a team to both technical and non-technical stakeholders.

Consider the following when developing your presentation and materials:

The presentation is a short introduction to your project, not a deep-dive into your development efforts:

    • Focus on key concepts or product features - why is this project exciting and worthwhile?
    • Tell a clear, cohesive story - you worked hard to define scope and requirements with your partner, keep your presentation within these boundaries.

After seeing your presentation, the audience should understand:

    • The purpose and goals of your project
        • Who your partner company is: their industry, market, vision/goals, etc.
        • The value proposition of your project to your partner
        • Who your user community is, and how your project supports their goals
    • What technologies you are using and why
    • Your overall project timeline, and what you have accomplished so far
    • Challenges you have faced, and how you have (or are) working through them

Remember to keep your design consistent with both your team's brand and the Clemson brand, including:

    • Visual elements - graphics, animations, font, color scheme, etc.
    • Audio elements - narration, sound effects, background music, etc.
  • Appropriate presentation attire is required (business casual), and team members should look coordinated
  • 5 mins max presentation, 3 mins for questions
  • Every team member must have a speaking role
  • Only one submission per team
assignments.name: Show and Tell 1

assignments.description:
You will work as a team to create your second Show and Tell for your project and deliver a presentation to the instructor and your classmates.

The purpose of this show and tell presentation is to:

  1. Give a status update on what you have accomplished since the first show and tell - focusing more on the technical aspects of your project
  2. Practice talking about your project before the end-of-semester event
  3. Receive feedback for improvement from the instructor and your peers on both your presentation materials and delivery

You will need to carefully consider what to include in your presentation materials, and what to leave out.

Consider the following when developing your presentation and materials - 

The presentation is a very short overview of your semester project.

    • Tell a clear, cohesive story - 
      • Keep your presentation tight within the boundaries of what you intended to do and actually accomplished
    • Focus on key concepts or product features - 
      • Why is this project exciting and worthwhile to the client and/or to the CS domain as a whole?
      • What buzzwords can you use to get people to want to come to your booth to find out more?

After seeing your presentation, the audience should understand:

    • The purpose and goals of your project
      • Who your client company is - industry, market space, etc.
      • Why they care about this project - the value proposition of your project to your client
      • Who your user community is, and how your project supports their goals
    • What technologies you are using and why (at a very high level)
    • What you have accomplished so far this semester
    • Challenges you faced, and how you worked through them
      • This personalizes your project for your audience

Remember to keep your design consistent with both your team's brand and the Clemson brand, including:

    • Visual elements - graphics, animations, font, color scheme, etc.
    • Audio elements - narration, sound effects, background music, etc. (if applicable)
  • 1 min/person max presentation, 5 mins for feedback
  • Presentation materials in .pdf format
  • Only one submission per team
assignments.name: Show and Tell 2
